The "+" style encoding is specified by HTML for the "application/x-www- 
fo=
rm-urlencoded" media type. Both HTML4.01 (http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/inte=
ract/forms.html#h-17.13.4 
) and HTML5 (http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/forms.ht=
ml#application-x-www-form-urlencoded-encoding-algorithm 
) describe this. W=
hen you use forms with method GET, the "+" character  
becomes part of the =
URI. For query parameter data, the framework will  
have to use HTML encodi=
ng rules.

Subbu

On Sep 21, 2009, at 12:40 AM, Sebastien Lambla wrote:

> =
Hi guys,
>
> this is an HTTP question, if you feel it's OT please discard :=
)
>
> The original URLs used + as a shorthand for spaces in querystrings.  =

> Browsers still implement this feature. Sadly, neither http nor html  
> =
(except for app/www-url-formencoded used as querystring in the HTML5  
> sp=
ec) imply this should still apply.
>
> Hence my question. Should an HTTP fr=
amework decode those + by  
> default for any http URI? I'm a bit split on =
the issue, as I don't  
> want to implement non-standard features, but I al=
so don't want to  
> p*ss off my users.
>
> Any suggestions?
>
> Seb
